 I believe the underlying or at least important assumption we make while using multiple-based methods is that the comparable group of companies are correctly valued by market 
 In the preceding quiz and lectures as well as evidence in real life confirms that companies may be either undervalued  or overvalued 
 If we consider, for example, oil and gas companies in emerging markets such as Russia and Ukraine where the state has almost a monopoly in the industry, the small cap privately owned oil and gas businesses cannot even find a proper peer group for comparison 
 The next important requirement for peers comparison is that the relevant group should be consistent in terms of revenue structure, business "maturity", debt or simply be alike 
 This constitutes another limitation for multiples based methods because  all the companies are different in their own way and normally our knowledge about them is based only on publicly awailable information 
 I understand that in this cours we are talking about companies who adhere to the same accounting and reporting standards such as IFRS , US GAAP, or other similar GAAPs (generally accepted accounting principles), while it may not always be the case as each country may have its own standards for financial disclosures 
 Hence , the definition of revenue and eventually profit shown by companies in a little known country may also be a subject for discrepancies with the peers in developed markets (countries) 
   The discussed in the course multiples based methods were based on current or past information as opposed to DCF method which takes into consideration future cash inflows and growth rates 
 That is in my opinion another disadvantage of multiples methods 
 Global demand for some products may change dramatically within industry 
 Again in energy sector the price for fossil fuel has dropped from 120 to below 50 usd/barrel (crude oil Brent) over past few years, the deplition of resources puts under going concern companies producers 
 While solar and renewables based energy companies are enjoying stronger growth and future demand (Tesla, Solaris, etc.) 
  Mobile phone companies: Nokia and Blackberry example of failures after years of significant growth couldn't serve as peers to Apple or Samsung (smartphones) while they seemed to be alike 
 And finally, the question about p/e for loss makers 
 Well, the purpose of any (commercial) firm is generating profits 
 The instinct says investing in loss making companies is a financial suicide 
 However if the company is undervalued due to its loss year, it's always worth to ask why there was a loss 
 And if the reason was adequate , the investment may be very well rewarded in the future 
 It often happens that company underwent some restructuring, was fined by regulator, posted impairment of assets or incurred a loss from discontinued operations 
 They not necessary lead to negative EBITDA but significantly lower it 
 Financial analysts and accountants call those adverse items as "one-offs" 
  One-offs do not typically happen in a due course of business but rather appear as "black swans" 
  In this case excluding one - offs from EBITDA or in other words -normalizing EBITDA-  may give us another more accurate picture on the value of the company

What we are talking about here is simply moral hazard, or the lack therein of bank policies 
 Looked at logically, there is no incentive for banks to moderate or indeed change any part of their lending practices 
 However, lending was never the issue for the so-called Great Recession 
 In fact, the depression from which we are still recovering was a result of the lack of segmentation in the Retail and Investment banking arms 
 What does this mean 
 The Great Depression was caused by massive speculative investment mania by ordinary citizens being allowed to borrow on margin into a roaring bull market where underlying value was detached from price of stocks 
 This inevitably led to a bubble or massive proportions and a resulting crash 
 However, many banks and lenders were allowed to go to the wall 
 Whilst some commentators believe that this was the root cause of the impact and sharp decline in the stock market value, the recovery was also relatively quick lasting approximately 3 years from start to finish 
 By contrast, because no banks were allowed to fail other than Lehman Brothers which was used an example of the systemic failure that could occur if other investment banks were allowed to go bust, this allowed the banking leaders (and root cause of the overvaluation of the housing market) to petition for TARP funding from the US government to the tune of $700 million in the first instance and much more subsequently as described in the previous video 
 Essentially, the government with the aid of Hank Paulson to justify the massive bail out of private banks with public money 
 It is worth remembering that government does not have any money other than through borrowing (bond market) or tax receipts, i.e 
 The earnings of private citizens and to a lesser extent companies who tend to offshore their earnings in tax friendly jurisdictions 
 So this is what is meant by Moral Hazard 
 Nothing other than the inefficient Dodd-Frank bill has been put in place to prevent a repeat of the Great Recession in the next couple of years 
 However, the bust this time will be much greater a) because the original debt has not been cleared by allowing banks to go bust and b) because the banks now believe that however they choose to make money they will be back-stopped by the tax payer - privatizing the profits and socializing the losses 
 In contrast, the Glass-Steagall act was introduced at the end of the Great Depression to separate Investment and Retail banking arms thereby preventing excessive risk taking by the speculation activity of Investment banks from adversely affecting the 'real economy' i.e 
 Business lending and private debt creation 
 The last part of this act was repealed by Clinton in 1999 under massive lobbying from the larger banks and this allowed the creation of banking monoliths such as Citigroup (so-called 'Too Big to Fail' institutions)and also the creation of extremely exotic synthetic investment products such as CDO's, securitized mortgages, virtualized securitized mortgage backed securities underwritten by the ratings agencies who were at once employed and expected to be dispassionate about the risk involved in producing these products which no-one actually understood 
 The cross-selling and  mixing of these products by investment banks meant that no-one understood exactly what assets belonged to whom, leading to a loss of confidence and so-called Credit Crunch when banks refused to lend to each without exorbitant inter-bank lending rates 
 The Central banks were then called upon to act as the lender of last resort which in this instance was the correct approach as the actual situation at the end of 2008 was much more serious than that in 1929 
 This would have been an effective strategy only in so far as it allowed risky assets to be disposed of and bank balance sheets brought under control reducing the leverage from in some cases up to 40:1 down to more historically manageable levels, perhaps around 9:1 
 This unhappily has not happened, and the opportunity has been lost to achieve this aim. This means that the bank balance sheets are in poor shape as they were and consumers are likewise carrying huge burdens of debt

I believe there are four scenarios/ reasons when multiples based valuation methods don't give a fair valuation of a company 
 1 
 When an entire industry is overvalued 
 This leads to multiples that are inaccurate 
 For example in the tech bubble in the early 2000s 
 Tech companies were all overvalued and hence multiples based valuation would give inaccurate valuations 
 2 
 When a company straddles two industries 
 For example uber 
 It is diifculy to place it in one particular industry 
 As it is part of the tech industry as well as the transportation industry 
 Choosing multiplies exclusively from one industry would lead to an inaccurate valuation of this company 
 In such scenarios the multiples based valuation will not work accurately 
 3 
 Multiples based valuation methods tend to ignore the unique characteristics of companies 
 For example their competitive advantage, management teams etc. These unique characteristics could make a company perform better or worse than the companies that their multiples are based off. Hence this would lead to inaccurate valuation of a company 
 4 
 Companies that have disruptive products and disruptive business models 
 Tend to outperform companies similar to them exponentially 
 Hence companies that are disruptive cannot be valued using a generic multiple based of comparable companies in a particular industry
